tit.cmt: ＊以下、浄土宗教団HPのterminologyを参照しましたhttp://www.jodo.org/terminology/japanese.html

sen.j: 浄土宗（じょうどしゅう）は、法然上人が開祖である、浄土教専修念仏を宗旨とする日本の仏教宗派の一つ。
sen.e: Jodo Shu is one of the denominations of Buddhism in Japan, which was founded by Honen Shonin and the teaching and practice of which is Jodo Kyo Senju-nembutsu (Exclusive Nembutsu).
sen.cmt: 法然上人→Honen Shonin （アポストロフィなし）
sen.e: Jodo Shu is one of the denominations of Buddhism in Japan, which was founded by Honen Shonin and the teaching and practice of which is Jodo Kyo Senju-nembutsu (Exclusive Nembutsu).
Jodo Shu is one of the denominations of Buddhism in Japan, which was founded by Honen Shonin and the teaching and practice of which is Jodo Kyo Senju-nenbutsu (Exclusive Nenbutsu).
sen.cmt: ローマ字をヘボン式に修正

sen.j: 本尊は阿弥陀如来（舟後光立弥陀）。
sen.e: Honzon (main image) is Amida Nyorai (Funagokoryumida).
Honzon (main image) is Amida Nyorai (Funagokoryumida).
Honzon (main image) is Amida Nyorai (Funagokoryumida).

sen.j: 法然（後の法然）は父の漆間時国の遺言通り僧侶になる事を誓う。
sen.e: Honen swore to be a monk, following a will of his father,URUMA no Tokikuni.
Honen swore to be a monk, following the will of his father, URUMA no Tokikuni.
Honen swore to be a monk, following the will of his father, URUMA no Tokikuni.

sen.j: 比叡山に登る前、叔父の菩提寺という寺院に行った。
sen.e: He was sent to his uncle's temple, Bodai-ji before he went to Mt.Hiei, the center of Buddhism study.
He was sent to his uncle's temple, Bodai-ji, before he went to Mt.Hiei, the center of Buddhist study.
He was sent to his uncle's temple, Bodai-ji, before he went to Mt. Hiei, the center of Buddhist study.

sen.j: そこの住職の観覚上人の下で勉学に励んだ。
sen.e: He studied hard underKangaku Shonin there.
He studied hard underKangaku Shonin there.
He studied hard under Kangaku Shonin there.

sen.j: しかし、4年の歳月が過ぎ師僧の観覚上人から「お前に教える事はもう何もない、比叡山に行ってはどうか」と言われ、勢至丸は比叡山へわずか13歳（1145年）で行く事となる。
sen.e: But after four years, his teacher monk Kangaku Shonin said Seihimaru 'I have nothing to teach you any more. How about going to study at Mt.Hiei?' and he went to Mt.Hiei in 1145, when he was only 13 years old.

But after four years, his teacher monk Kangaku Shonin said to Seishimaru 'I have nothing to teach you any more. How about going to study at Mt. Hiei?', so he went to Mt. Hiei in 1145, when he was only 13 years old.
sen.cmt: added "to"; corrected spelling of Seishimaru; added spaces after "Mt."
sen.e: But after four years, his teacher monk Kangaku Shonin said to Seishimaru 'I have nothing to teach you any more. How about going to study at Mt. Hiei?', so he went to Mt. Hiei in 1145, when he was only 13 years old.

sen.j: その後、叡山根本中堂に於いて源光 (僧侶)上人より学ぶ。
sen.e: After that he learned Buddhism under Genko Shonin at Eizan Komponchido.
After that he learned Buddhism under Genko Shonin at Eizan Komponchido.
After that he learned Buddhism under Genko Shonin at Eizan Komponchudo.

sen.j: また、源光上人が勉学を教えられなくなり、皇円阿闍梨の下で学ぶ。
sen.e: After Seihimaru had learned everything Genko Shonin could have taught, he started to study under Koen Ajaru.
After Seishimaru had learned everything Genko Shonin could have taught, he started to study under Koen Ajaru.
After Seishimaru had learned everything Genko Shonin could have taught, he started to study under Koen Ajari.

sen.j: ここで勢至丸・15歳（1147年）、正式に得度する。
sen.e: Seihimaru was ordained officially by Koen in1147, when he was 15.
sen.cmt: 得度→Tokudoとありましたが変更しました
sen.e: Seishimaru was ordained officially by Koen in 1147, when he was 15.
Seishimaru was ordained officially by Koen in 1147, when he was 15.

sen.j: 勢至丸・18歳（1150年）の時、青龍寺 (大津市坂本)の別所に移り慈眼房叡空上人に師事して法然房源空（源光・叡空より一字ずつ名を貰った）と名のる。
sen.e: In 1150 (18 years old), Seisimaru moved to Besho of Seiryu-ji Temple (in Sakamoto,Otsu city) was taught by Jigem-bo Eiku Shonin, named Honen-bo Genku (used each one Kanji character from Genko and Eiko).
sen.cmt: 別所は地名があります。慈眼房叡空上人もアポストロフィなしに変更しました。
sen.e: In 1150 (18 years old), Seishimaru moved to Besho of Seiryu-ji Temple (in Sakamoto, Otsu city), was taught by Jigenbo Eiku Shonin, named Honen-bo Genku (used one Kanji character each from Genko and Eiko).

In 1150 (18 years old), Seishimaru moved to Bessho of Seiryu-ji Temple (in Sakamoto, Otsu city), was taught by Jigenbo Eiku Shonin, named Honen-bo Genku (used one Kanji character each from Genko and Eiko).

sen.j: 承安 (日本)5年（1175年）43歳の時、善導大師の観無量寿経疏（観経疏）によって専修念仏に進み、比叡山を下りて東山吉水に住み、念仏の教えを弘めた。
sen.e: In 1175 (Shoan 5), when he was 43, Honen realized the truth of Senju-nembutsu by Kanmuryojukyosho(Kangyosho,Commentary on the Meditation Sutra) written by Zendo Daishi, so he left Mt.Hiei for Higashiyama Yoshimizu and began to spread the teaching of the nembutsu.
sen.cmt: 観無量寿経疏→Kanmuryoju-kyosho (Commentary on the Meditation Sutra）と括弧内に英訳をつけました。
sen.e: In 1175, when he was 43, Honen realized the truth of Senju-nembutsu by Kanmuryojukyosho(Kangyosho,Commentary on the Meditation Sutra), written by Zendo Daishi, so he left Mt. Hiei for Higashiyama Yoshimizu and began to spread the teaching of the nembutsu.
sen.cmt: deleted Japanese date; corrected punctuation and spacing
sen.e: In 1175, when he was 43, Honen realized the truth of Senju-nenbutsu by Kanmuryojukyosho (Kangyosho, Commentary on the Meditation Sutra), written by Zendo Daishi, so he left Mt. Hiei for Higashiyama Yoshimizu and began to spread the teaching of the nenbutsu.
sen.cmt: 全角の（を半角に、スペースを挿入、スペル修正

sen.j: この年が、浄土宗の立教開宗の年とされる。
sen.e: It is said that this is the beginning of Jodo Shu.
It is said that this is the beginning of Jodo Shu.
It is said that this is the beginning of Jodo Shu.

sen.j: その観経疏にある立教に至った文字は、
sen.e: The words of Kangyosho, which made Honen found Jodo Shu are:
The words of Kangyosho, which made Honen found Jodo Shu are:
The words of Kangyosho, which made Honen found Jodo Shu are:

sen.j: 一心に専ら弥陀の名を称えいつでも何処でも時間の短い長いに関係なく常にこれを念頭に置き継続する事が往生への道である。
sen.e: The way of Ojo(Birth in the Pure Land) is to continue to recite the name of Mida (Amida) intently whenever and wherever, regaredlss of length of time.
The way of Ojo (birth in the Pure Land) is to continue to recite the name of Mida (Amida) intently whenever and wherever, regaredlss of length of time.
The way of Ojo (birth in the Pure Land) is to continue to recite the name of Mida (Amida) intently whenever and wherever, regardless of length of time.

sen.j: その理由は弥陀の本願に順ずるからである。
sen.e: That is because it leads to the true wish of Mida.
That is because it leads to the true wish of Mida.
That is because it leads to the true wish of Mida.

sen.j: 一心専念弥陀名号
sen.e: Recite the name of Mida intently.
Recite the name of Mida intently.
Recite the name of Mida intently.

sen.j: 行住坐臥不問時節久近
sen.e: Whenever and whereevr, it doesn't matter how long you recite.
Whenever and wherever, it doesn't matter how long you recite.
Whenever and wherever, it doesn't matter how long you recite.

sen.j: 念念不捨者是名正定之業
sen.e: Continue to recite the name of Mida and it is the true way for Ojo.
Continue to recite the name of Mida and it is the true way for Ojo.
Continue to recite the name of Mida and it is the true way for Ojo.

sen.j: 順彼佛願故
sen.e: That is because it leads to the true wish of Mida.
That is because it leads to the true wish of Mida.
That is because it leads to the true wish of Mida.

sen.j: 「南無阿弥陀仏」＝阿弥陀仏に帰依します。
sen.e: Namu Amida Butsu' means to believe Amida Butsu.
"Namu Amida Butsu" means to believe in Amida Butsu.
sen.cmt: changed to double quotation marks; added "in"
sen.e: "Namu Amida Butsu" means to believe in Amida Butsu.

sen.j: 弥陀佛の選択 (仏教)によって、浄土宗における念仏はここから始まったと言っても良い、。
sen.e: It is said the nembustu of Jodo Shu has begun to from these words by selecting Mida Butsu.
It is said the nembustu of Jodo Shu began with the selection of these words, Mida Butsu.
It is said the nenbustu of Jodo Shu began with the selection of these words, Mida Butsu.

sen.j: 『選択本願念仏集』が浄土宗の根本聖典となっており、教義の集大成となっている。
sen.e: 'Senchaku Hongan Nembutsu Shu (Passages on the Selection of the Nembutsu in the Original Vow) is the main sacred book, which is a compilation of dogma.
sen.cmt: 選択本願念仏集→Senchaku Hongan Nembutsu-shu (Passages on the Selection of the Nembutsu in the Original Vow)と括弧内に英訳をつけました。
sen.e: "Senchaku Hongan Nembutsu Shu" (Passages on the Selection of the Nembutsu in the Original Vow) is the main sacred book, which is a compilation of dogma.
"Senchaku Hongan nenbutsu Shu" (Passages on the Selection of the nenbutsu in the Original Vow) is the main sacred book, which is a compilation of dogma.
sen.cmt: 全角スペースを半角に置換、スペル修正

sen.j: また、浄土宗の立教と共に旧来の仏教である天台宗や奈良の興福寺から批判の声が上がり、承元元年（1207年）、法然は讃岐国へ流罪にさせられる（承元の法難）が、その地においても布教をした。
sen.e: When Honen founded Jodo Shu, he was criticized by old temples such as Tendai denomination and Kofuku-ji temple of Nara, and exiled to Sanuki province (Jogen persecution), but he propagated Jodo Shu there as well.

When Honen founded Jodo Shu, he was criticized by old temples such as Tendai denomination and Kofuku-ji temple of Nara, and exiled to Sanuki province (Jogen persecution), but he propagated Jodo Shu there as well.

When Honen founded Jodo Shu, he was criticized by old temples such as Tendai denomination and Kofuku-ji temple of Nara, and exiled to Sanuki province (Jogen persecution), but he propagated Jodo Shu there as well.

sen.j: その後、法然は赦免されたものの、京都への入京を禁じられたために、摂津国勝尾寺を拠点に布教を続けた。
sen.e: After that he was pardoned but forbidden to enter Kyoto, so he continued to propagation based at Katsuo-ji Temple in Settsu Province.
After that he was pardoned but forbidden to enter Kyoto, so he continued to propagation based at Katsuo-ji Temple in Settsu Province.
After that he was pardoned but forbidden to enter Kyoto, so he continued to propagation based at Katsuo-ji Temple in Settsu Province.

sen.j: 法然は建暦元年（1211年）に京都への復帰を許されたものの、翌年に80歳の生涯を閉じている。
sen.e: Honen was allowed to come back to Kyoto in 1211(Kenreki 1), but passed away at the age of 80 next year.
Honen was allowed to come back to Kyoto in 1211(Kenreki 1), but passed away at the age of 80 next year.
Honen was allowed to come back to Kyoto in 1211(Kenreki 1), but passed away at the age of 80 next year.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 法然の没後、長老の信空 (浄土宗)が後継となったものの、証空・弁長・幸西・長西・隆寛・親鸞ら門人の間で法然の教義に対する解釈で微妙な違いが生じていた。
sen.e: After Honen passed away, Shinku,an elder of disciples, succeeded Jodo Shu denomination, but there were subtle difference in the interpretation of the dogma of Honen between disciples such as Shoku,Bencho,Kosai,Chosai,Ryukan and Shinran.

After Honen passed away, Shinku, an elder disciple, succeeded the Jodo Shu denomination, but there were subtle differences in the interpretation of the dogma of Honen between disciples such as Shoku, Bencho, Kosai, Chosai, Ryukan and Shinran.
sen.cmt: added missing spaces; corrected number agreement
sen.e: After Honen passed away, Shinku, an elder disciple, succeeded the Jodo Shu denomination, but there were subtle differences in the interpretation of the dogma of Honen between disciples such as Shoku, Bencho, Kosai, Chosai, Ryukan and Shinran.

sen.j: 嘉禄3年（1227年）、再び専修念仏の停止が命ぜられて、浄土門では大きな被害を蒙り、以後、法然教団の分派が加速することとなった（嘉禄の法難）。
sen.e: In 1227 (Karoku 3) Senju-nembutsu was forbidden again, and Jodo Shu was damaged heavily and accelerated for separation (Karoku persecution).
In 1227, Senju-nembutsu was forbidden again, and Jodo Shu was damaged heavily and moved toward separation (Karoku persecution).
sen.cmt: deleted Japanese date; rephrased for clarity; removed double-width space
sen.e: In 1227, Senju-nenbutsu was forbidden again, and Jodo Shu was damaged heavily and moved toward separation (Karoku persecution).

sen.j: 事の発端には、法性寺の寺宝が盗まれた際に、念仏者が盗賊団の一味として疑われたことがある。
sen.e: The reason of this persecution was nembutsu priests was suspected as rubbers when the treasure of Hossho-ji Temple was stolen.
The reason for this persecution was that nembutsu priests were suspected of robbery when the treasure of Hossho-ji Temple was stolen.
The reason for this persecution was that nenbutsu priests were suspected of robbery when the treasure of Hossho-ji Temple was stolen.

sen.j: また、延暦寺の僧徒たちが念仏者を襲撃したりし、『選択本願念仏集』は禁書扱いを受け、東山 (京都府)大谷の法然墓堂も破壊された。
sen.e: In addition, monks of Enryaku-ji Temple attacked nembutsu priests,'Senchanku Hongan Nembutsu Shu (Passages on the Selection of the Nembutsu in the Original Vow)' was forbidden to read, and the Hall of Honen's grave at Higashiyama Otani (Kyoto) was destroyed.

In addition, monks of Enryaku-ji Temple attacked nembutsu priests, "Senchanku Hongan Nembutsu Shu (Passages on the Selection of the Nembutsu in the Original Vow)" was banned, and Honen's mausoleum at Higashiyama Otani (Kyoto) was destroyed.
sen.cmt: changed to double quotes; changed to "banned"; changed to "mausoleum"
sen.e: In addition, monks of Enryaku-ji Temple attacked nenbutsu priests, "Senchaku Hongan nenbutsu Shu (Passages on the Selection of the nenbutsu in the Original Vow)" was banned, and Honen's mausoleum at Higashiyama Otani (Kyoto) was destroyed.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除、スペル修正

sen.j: なお、この際に幸西は壱岐国に、隆寛は陸奥国に配流されている。
sen.e: At this time Kosai was exiled to Iki Province and Ryukan to Mutsu Province as well.
At this time Kosai was exiled to Iki Province and Ryukan to Mutsu Province as well.
At this time Kosai was exiled to Iki Province and Ryukan to Mutsu Province as well.

sen.j: 法然の遺骸は、太秦広隆寺の来迎房円空に託され、1228年（安貞2年）に西山の粟生野で荼毘に付された。
sen.e: Honen's body was accepted by raigo Enku of Uzumasa Koryu-ji Temple and cremated at Ao'no in Nishiyama.
Honen's body was accepted by raigo Enku of Uzumasa Koryu-ji Temple and cremated at Ao'no in Nishiyama.
Honen's body was accepted by Raigo Enku of Uzumasa Koryu-ji Temple and cremated at Ao'no in Nishiyama.

sen.j: その後、浄土四流（じょうどしりゅう）という流れが形成される。
sen.e: After that, Jodo shiryu (four sects of Jodo Shu) were founded.
After that, Jodo shiryu (four sects of Jodo Shu) were founded.
After that, Jodo shiryu (four sects of Jodo Shu) were founded.

sen.j: すなわち、信空の没後、京都の浄土宗の主流となった証空の西山義、九州の草野氏の庇護を受けた弁長の鎮西義、東国への流刑を機に却って同地で多念義を広めた隆寛の長楽寺義、京都で証空に対抗して所業本願義を説いた長西の九品寺義の4派を指す。
sen.e: It means the four sects, that is, Seizan-gi of Shoku, which were mainstream of Jodo Shu after Shinku died, Chinzei-gi of Bencho who were patronized by Kusano clan in Kyosyu, Chorakuji-gi of Ryukan who spread Tanen-gi in Eastern area after exile there, Kuhonji-gi of Chosei who taught Shogyohongan-gi against Shoku in Kyoto.

That is the four sects that were the mainstream of Jodo Shu after Shinku's death, Seizan-gi of Shoku, Chinzei-gi of Bencho who was patronized by the Kusano clan in Kyoshu, Chorakuji-gi of Ryukan who spread Tanen-gi in Eastern area after exile there, Kuhonji-gi of Chosei who taught Shogyohongan-gi against Shoku in Kyoto.

That is the four sects that were the mainstream of Jodo Shu after Shinku's death, Seizan-gi of Shoku, Chinzei-gi of Bencho who was patronized by the Kusano clan in Kyushu, Chorakuji-gi of Ryukan who spread Tanen-gi in Eastern area after exile there, Kuhonji-gi of Chosei who taught Shogyohongan-gi against Shoku in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: スペースの重複を削除、スペル修正

sen.j: もっとも当時の有力な集団の1つであった親鸞の教団はその没後に浄土真宗として事実上独立することとなりこの4流には含まれておらず、他にも嵯峨 (京都市)二尊院の湛空や知恩院を再興した源智、一念義を唱えた幸西など4流に加わらずに独自の教団を構成した集団が乱立した。
sen.e: These four sects do not include Shinran's sect, one of the most strongest sects at that time, which become independent as Judo Shinshu after he died. Other independent sects flooded by other priests such as Tanku of Nison-in Temple in Saga (Kyoto), Genchi who revived Chion-in Temple and Kosei who introduced Ichinen-gi.

These four sects do not include Shinran's sect, one of the strongest sects at that time, which became independent as Jodo Shinshu after he died. Other independent sects were founded left and right by other priests such as Tanku of Nison-in Temple in Saga (Kyoto), Genchi who revived Chion-in Temple and Kosei who introduced Ichinen-gi.

These four sects do not include Shinran's sect, one of the strongest sects at that time, which became independent as Jodo Shinshu after he died. Other independent sects were founded left and right by other priests such as Tanku of Nison-in Temple in Saga (Kyoto), Genchi who revived Chion-in Temple and Kosei who introduced Ichinen-gi.

sen.j: だが、中世を通じて残ったのは浄土真宗を別にすると西山義と鎮西義の2つであり、この両義の教団を「西山派」「鎮西派」と称することとなる。
sen.e: But only Seizan-gi and Chinzei-gi were left through the Middle ages other than Jodo Shinshu,and they were called Seizan School and Chinzei School.
But only Seizan-gi and Chinzei-gi remained through the Middle ages, other than Jodo Shinshu, and they were called Seizan School and Chinzei School.
But only Seizan-gi and Chinzei-gi remained through the Middle ages, other than Jodo Shinshu, and they were called Seizan School and Chinzei School.

sen.j: 一方、鎌倉においても鎌倉幕府によって念仏停止などの弾圧が行われたが、後には西山派は北条氏一族の中にも受け入れられて鎌倉弁ヶ谷に拠点を築いた。
sen.e: On the other hand, Kamakura Shogunate oppressed Jodo shu to cease nembutsu in Kamakura, but Seizan-ha was welcomed by Hojo clan later and build a base in Bengayatasu of Kamakura.
On the other hand, the Kamakura Shogunate oppressed Jodo Shu to stop nembutsu in Kamakura, but Seizan-ha was welcomed by Hojo clan later and built a base in Bengayatasu of Kamakura.
On the other hand, the Kamakura Shogunate oppressed Jodo Shu to stop nenbutsu in Kamakura, but Seizan-ha was welcomed by Hojo clan later and built a base in Bengayatasu of Kamakura.

sen.j: 一方、鎮西派を開いた弁長の弟子であった良忠も鎌倉の悟真寺（現在の光明寺_(鎌倉市)）を中心とした関東各地に勢力を伸ばしていった。
sen.e: Moreover, Ryochu,who were a disciple of Bencho,founder of Chinzei-ha, had established his influence in Kanto area based on Goshin-ji Temple(present Komyo-ji Temple (Kamakura city)).
Moreover, Ryochu, who was a disciple of Bencho, founder of Chinzei-ha, had established his influence in Kanto area based on Goshin-ji Temple (present Komyo-ji Temple in Kamakura city).
Moreover, Ryochu, who was a disciple of Bencho, founder of Chinzei-ha, had established his influence in Kanto area based on Goshin-ji Temple (present Komyo-ji Temple in Kamakura city).

sen.j: 鎌倉にある極楽寺_(鎌倉市)は真言律宗になる前は浄土宗寺院であったとも言われ、高徳院（鎌倉大仏）も同地における代表的な浄土宗寺院である（ただし、公式に浄土宗寺院になったのは江戸時代とも言われ、その初期については諸説がある）。
sen.e: Gokuraku-ji Temple in Kamakura (Kamakura city) was said to have been a Jodo Shu Temple before Shingon-risshu Temple and Kotoku-in (Kamakura Daibutsu) is a representative Jodo Shu temple in Kamakura (it is said that it was in Edo period it became Jodo Shu Temple officially, there are various opinions on the beginning.

Gokuraku-ji Temple in Kamakura (Kamakura city) was said to have been a Jodo Shu Temple before becoming a Shingon-risshu temple, and Kotoku-in (Kamakura Daibutsu) is a representative Jodo Shu temple in Kamakura (it is said that it was in the Edo period that it officially became a Jodo Shu Temple, there are various opinions about the early period.
sen.cmt: removed double-width spaces; edited for clarity
sen.e: Gokuraku-ji Temple in Kamakura (Kamakura city) was said to have been a Jodo Shu Temple before becoming a Shingon-risshu temple, and Kotoku-in (Kamakura Daibutsu) is a representative Jodo Shu temple in Kamakura (it is said that it was in the Edo period that it officially became a Jodo Shu Temple, there are various opinions about the early period.
sen.cmt: 全角スペースを半角に置換

sen.j: だが、西山派は証空の死後、西谷流・深草流・東山流・嵯峨流に分裂し、鎮西派も良忠の死後に白旗派・名越派・藤田派・一条派・木幡派・三条派に分裂するなど、浄土宗は更なる分裂の時代を迎える事になる。
sen.e: But Jodo Shu fell into the are of separation; Nishiyama-ha separated to Nishitani-ryu,Fukakusa-ryu,Higashiyama-ryu and Saga-ryu after Shoku died, and Chinzei-ha separated Shirohata-ha,Nagoe-ha,Fujita-ha,Ichijo-ha,Kobata-ha and Sanjo-ha after Yoshitada died.

But Jodo Shu fell into an era of separation; Nishiyama-ha separated to Nishitani-ryu, Fukakusa-ryu, Higashiyama-ryu and Saga-ryu after Shoku died, and Chinzei-ha separated into Shirohata-ha, Nagoe-ha, Fujita-ha, Ichijo-ha, Kobata-ha and Sanjo-ha after Yoshitada died.

But Jodo Shu fell into an era of separation; Nishiyama-ha separated to Nishitani-ryu, Fukakusa-ryu, Higashiyama-ryu and Saga-ryu after Shoku died, and Chinzei-ha separated into Shirohata-ha, Nagoe-ha, Fujita-ha, Ichijo-ha, Kobata-ha and Sanjo-ha after Yoshitada died.

sen.j: その後南北朝時代 (日本)から室町時代にかけて、鎮西派の中でも藤田派の聖観・良栄、白旗派の聖冏・聖聡が現れて宗派を興隆して西山派及び鎮西派の他の流派を圧倒した。
sen.e: From Nambokucho period (Japan) to Muromachi period Shokan and Ryouei of Fujita-ha and Shogei and Shoso of Shirohata-ha appeared among Chinze-ha and founded new sects, overcoming Seizan-ha and other sects of Chinzei-ha.

From the Nambokucho period to the Muromachi period Shokan and Ryouei of Fujita-ha and Shogei and Shoso of Shirohata-ha appeared within Chinzei-ha and founded new sects, overcoming Seizan-ha and other sects of Chinzei-ha.

From the Nanbokucho period to the Muromachi period Shokan and Ryoei of Fujita-ha and Shogei and Shoso of Shirohata-ha appeared within Chinzei-ha and founded new sects, overcoming Seizan-ha and other sects of Chinzei-ha.
sen.cmt: スペースの重複を削除、スペル修正

sen.j: 特に聖冏は浄土宗に宗脈・戒脈の相承があるとして「五重相伝」の法を唱え、血脈・教義の組織化を図って宗門を統一しようとした。
sen.e: Especially, Seido insisted the rule of Goju-soden(Fivefold Transmission) because Jodo Shu has a succession of dogma and genealogy, and tried to integrate various sects by organization of genealogy and dogma.
sen.cmt: 宗脈・戒脈→定訳が見当たらないので合わせてgenealogyとしました。
sen.e: Especially, Seido insisted on the rule of Goju-soden (Fivefold Transmission) because Jodo Shu has a succession of dogma and genealogy, and tried to integrate various sects by organization of genealogy and dogma.

Especially, Seido insisted on the rule of Goju-soden (Fivefold Transmission) because Jodo Shu has a succession of dogma and genealogy, and tried to integrate various sects by organization of genealogy and dogma.
sen.cmt: スペースの重複を削除

sen.j: 聖聡は増上寺を創建し、その孫弟子にあたる愚底は松平親忠に乞われて大樹寺を創建した。
sen.e: Shoso build Zojo-ji Temple and his desciple,Gutei, build Daiju-ji Temple asked by Chikatada MATSUDAIRA.
Shoso built Zojo-ji Temple and his desciple, Gutei, built Daiju-ji Temple at the request of Chikatada MATSUDAIRA.
Shoso built Zojo-ji Temple and his disciple, Gutei, built Daiju-ji Temple at the request of Chikatada MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 応仁の乱後、白旗派の手によって再興された知恩院は天正3年（1575年）に正親町天皇より浄土宗本寺としての承認を受け、諸国の浄土宗僧侶への香衣付与・剥奪の権限を与えられた（「毀破綸旨」）。
sen.e: Chion-in, which was revived by Shirohata-ha after Onin War, was admitted as the head temple of Jodo Shu by Emperor Ogimachi in 1575(Tensho 3) and given authority to give or deprive sacred robe to Jodo Shu monks in Japan ('Kiharinji').

Chion-in, which was revived by Shirohata-ha after the Onin War, was admitted as the head temple of Jodo Shu by Emperor Ogimachi in 1575 and given authority to grant or deny vestments to Jodo Shu monks in Japan ('Kiharinji').

Chion-in, which was revived by Shirohata-ha after the Onin War, was admitted as the head temple of Jodo Shu by Emperor Ogimachi in 1575 and given authority to grant or deny vestments to Jodo Shu monks in Japan ('Kiharinji').

sen.j: 更に松平親忠の末裔である徳川家康が江戸幕府を開いた事によって浄土宗は手厚い保護を受けることになる。
sen.e: In addition, after the foundation of Edo Shogunate by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who was a descendant of Chikatada MATSUDAIRA, Jodo Shu had protected heavily.
In addition, after the foundation of the Edo Shogunate by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who was a descendant of Chikatada MATSUDAIRA, Jodo Shu was protected heavily.
In addition, after the foundation of the Edo Shogunate by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, who was a descendant of Chikatada MATSUDAIRA, Jodo Shu was protected heavily.

sen.j: 特に知恩院の尊照と増上寺の存応は、家康の崇敬を受けた。
sen.e: Especially Sonsho in Chion-in and Son'o in Zojo-ji Temple were respected by Ieyasu.
Sonsho in Chion-in and Son'o in Zojo-ji Temple were especially respected by Ieyasu.
Sonsho in Chion-in and Son'o in Zojo-ji Temple were especially respected by Ieyasu.

sen.j: 元和 (日本)元年（1615年）に寺院諸法度の一環として浄土宗法度が制定され、知恩院が門跡寺院・第一位の本山とされ、増上寺はこれより下位に置かれたものの、「大本山」の称号と宗務行政官庁である「総録所」が設置された。
sen.e: In 1615 (Genwa 1) Jodoshu hatto was established as one of the rules of Jiin shohatto, in which Chion-in was recognized as the head temple, and Zojo-ji Temple was given the name of Daihonzan and Sorokusho(a government office of religion) was founded there although it had a lower position than Chion-in..

In 1615 Jodoshu hatto was established as one of the rules of Jiin shohatto, in which Chion-in was recognized as the head temple, and Zojo-ji Temple was given the name of Daihonzan and Sorokusho (a government office of religion) was founded there although it had a lower position than Chion-in.

In 1615 Jodoshu hatto was established as one of the rules of Jiin shohatto, in which Chion-in was recognized as the head temple, and Zojo-ji Temple was given the name of Daihonzan and Sorokusho (a government office of religion) was founded there although it had a lower position than Chion-in.

sen.j: なお、この際西山派に対しては別個に「浄土西山派法度」を出されている。
sen.e: At this time Edo government established Jodo Seizan-ha hatto for Seizan-ha independently.
At this time the Edo government established Jodo Seizan-ha hatto for Seizan-ha independently.
At this time the Edo government established Jodo Seizan-ha hatto for Seizan-ha independently.

sen.j: だが、これによって浄土宗は徳川将軍家、ひいては幕藩体制の保護を受けることとなる。
sen.e: By these rules Jodo Shu had protected by Tokugawa Shogunate, in other words, Shogunate and domain system.
By these rules Jodo Shu was protected by Tokugawa Shogunate, in other words, Shogunate and domain system.
By these rules Jodo Shu was protected by Tokugawa Shogunate, in other words, Shogunate and domain system.

sen.j: 廃仏毀釈の混乱の中から養鸕徹定・福田行誡らによって近代化が図られて白旗派が名越派などを統合する形で鎮西派が統一されて現在の浄土宗の原型が成立する。
sen.e: After the chaos of Haibutsu kishaku Tetsujo UGAI and Gyokai FUKUDA tackled modernization of Jodo Shu. Integration of Chinzei-ha by that Shirohata-ha unified Nagosi-ha and others led to the prototype of present Jodo Shu..

After the chaos of Haibutsu kishaku, Tetsujo UGAI and Gyokai FUKUDA tackled modernization of Jodo Shu. Integration of Chinzei-ha by the Shirohata-ha that unified Nagoshi-ha and others led to the prototype of present Jodo Shu.

After the chaos of Haibutsu kishaku, Tetsujo UGAI and Gyokai FUKUDA tackled modernization of Jodo Shu. Integration of Chinzei-ha by the Shirohata-ha that unified Nagoshi-ha and others led to the prototype of present Jodo Shu.

sen.j: 第2次世界大戦後は金戒光明寺を中心とした黒谷浄土宗、知恩院を中心とする本派浄土宗（浄土宗本派）が分立するが、昭和36年（1961年）の法然750年忌を機に浄土宗本派が復帰、16年後に黒谷浄土宗も復帰した。
sen.e: After World WarⅡ,Kutodani Jodoshu based on Konkaikomkyo-ji Temple and Honpa Jodoshu (Jodoshu Hompa) based on Chion-in became independent, but in 1961 (Showa 36) when a memorial ceremony of 750 years after Honen died was held, Jodoshu Hompa returned and Kurodani Jodoshi also returned 16 years later.

After World War, Kutodani Jodoshu, based in Konkaikomkyo-ji Temple, and Honpa Jodoshu (Jodoshu Hompa), based in Chion-in, became independent, but in 1961, when a memorial ceremony for the 750th anniversary of Honen's death was held, Jodoshu Hompa returned and Kurodani Jodoshi also returned 16 years later.

After World War, Kurodani Jodoshu, based in Konkaikonmyo-ji Temple, and Honpa Jodoshu (Jodoshu Honpa), based in Chion-in, became independent, but in 1961, when a memorial ceremony for the 750th anniversary of Honen's death was held, Jodoshu Honpa returned and Kurodani Jodoshu also returned 16 years later.
sen.cmt: スペースの重複を削除、スペル修正

sen.j: 現在の宗教法人としての「浄土宗」の代表役員は宗務総長、責任役員は内局と呼ばれている。
sen.e: The representative director of Jodo Shu as a present religious corporation is called 'Shumu Socho' and responsible director is called 'Naikyoku'.
The representative director of Jodo Shu as a present religious corporation is called 'Shumu Socho' and responsible director is called 'Naikyoku'.
The representative director of Jodo Shu as a present religious corporation is called 'Shumu Socho' and responsible director is called 'Naikyoku'.

sen.j: 一方、西山派は現在も浄土宗とは別個に西山浄土宗・西山禅林寺派・西山深草派の3派が並立した状態が続いている。
sen.e: On the other hand, Seizan-ha has been separated to Seizan Jodoshu,Seizan Zenrinji-ha and Seizan Fukakusa-ha.
On the other hand, Seizan-ha has been separated into Seizan Jodoshu, Seizan Zenrinji-ha and Seizan Fukakusa-ha.
On the other hand, Seizan-ha has been separated into Seizan Jodoshu, Seizan Zenrinji-ha and Seizan Fukakusa-ha.

sen.j: また、江戸時代の改革運動の際に分裂した浄土宗捨世派の勢力も存在する。
sen.e: Jodoshu Shasei-ha, which was separated in the reform movement in Edo period also has remained.
Jodoshu Shasei-ha, which was separated in the reform movement in Edo period, also has remained.
Jodoshu Shasei-ha, which was separated in the reform movement in Edo period, also has remained.
